title: RWE to sell 49% stake in UK offshore wind farm to Greencoat for £648m
lead: The project which is off the coast of East Yorkshire has an installed capacity of 219MW

title: Almost 41% of Brits are ‘willing to pay more to commute on a hydrogen train or bus’
lead: Almost 41% of Brits would pay an additional £1 per day in order to lower the carbon footprint of their commute, according to a new survey

title: Global investors plan to double proportion of renewable investments in next five years
lead: This rise is expected to continue to 10.8% over a ten-year timeframe as global climate action continues to ramp up on the road to reaching net zero by 2050

title: EDF seeks partners for hydrogen and direct capture demos at Sizewell C
lead: It has issued two ‘expression of interest’ proposals and is calling on companies with relevant expertise to come forward to help deliver the projects

title: Octopus Energy launches services in German market
lead: The British retail energy firm aims to target one million customers in Germany by 2024

title: UK ranked fifth-best country for renewable deployment
lead: The US has held its place at the top of the global ranking, while China remains in the second spot, according to EY’s Renewable Energy Country Attractiveness Index

title: EU approves €280m for environment, nature and climate action projects
lead: The funding is expected to trigger total investments of nearly €590m

title: New inquiry into renewable energy support launched in Wales
lead: It will look for potential opportunities for development and deployment of renewable energy in Wales and how Cardiff and Westminster should work together to support them

title: ISO 50001: the pros and cons of an energy management system
lead: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) states that to prevent catastrophic climate impacts, global temperature rise must be kept below 1.5°C.

title: UK billpayers ‘could see energy bills rise by up to £63m’ as December begins
lead: Uswitch warns 816,000 households could be affected by fixed deals ending and suggests they could see bills rise by an average of £155 as they are moved onto standard variable tariffs
